p: Nevertheless, TBE incidence is generally projected to move to higher altitudes and latitudes in line with the distribution of I. ricinus, resulting in an increased risk in some parts of northern and central Europe (notwithstanding the potential implementation of targeted vaccination programmes and enhanced TBE surveillance). At the same time, the risk of TBE is largely anticipated to diminish in the south of Europe. Likewise, milder winters may enable the extension of Lyme borreliosis to higher altitudes and latitudes, predominantly in the north of Europe, but the risk is expected to diminish in areas of Europe that are projected to suffer extended dry spells (Semenza and Menne 2009).
